summary.seg: This manuscript is a composite made up of parts copied at dates between the early 16th century and 1690 and subsequently bound together. It contains a varied Greek Miscellany of texts including works on ecclesiastical organisation and history, canon law, chronicles, the monuments of Constantinople and recipes.

The oldest part of the manuscript is brief, containing two letters written by a man named Andronikos to one Demetrios, on paper whose watermarks place it in the first half of the 16th century. One of these letters heaps praise on the city of Venice in tones that suggest that writer and recipient may have belonged to the Greek community of Venice or one of its overseas territories.

Most of the older parts of the manuscript were copied by Ioannes Malaxos, a prolific scribe and probably a monk, who worked in Constantinople in the second half of the 16th century. He may well have been related to two contemporary scribes originally from Nauplion in the Peloponnese, Manuel and Nikolaos Malaxos. He collaborated on occasion with Manuel after the latter moved to Constantinople, and both of them worked with another Naupliot scribe in the city, Theodosios Zygomalas.

Malaxos himself is believed to have composed various texts in the manuscript relating to the historic buildings and monuments of Constantinople and its environs, including descriptions of the city gates and of the church of the Pammakaristos, at that time the seat of the Patriarch of Constantinople, and its funerary monuments. Besides those from the tombs of the Pammakaristos, inscriptions transcribed by Malaxos included one from the walls of Chalkedon, across the Bosphoros, and another bearing a Novel (law) of the Emperor Manuel I, then at the Pammakaristos but transferred in 1567 to the mausoleum being prepared for the reigning Sultan Suleiman II. Other texts copied by Malaxos include short chronicles and chronological lists of office-holders, lists of ecclesiastical offices and recipes for products including medicines, inks and soap.

The material on the Pammakaristos enables the completion of the component of the manuscript in which it appears to be placed between 1572 and 1587. The former year is the last in which a son of the voivod Alexander of Moldavia, whose tomb is mentioned here, is known to have been alive; the latter is the year in which the Pammakaristos, described here as the patriarchal church was seized by the Ottoman government, prior to being turned into a mosque (Burke, 'Studi su copisti', p.230). There are two physically distinct portions of the manuscript copied by Malaxos, which may be of different dates. The other must date from later than 1566, since Malaxos added an entry to the end of a short chronicle he had copied, recording the accession in that year of the Ottoman Sultan Selim II.

The later component parts of the manuscript were copied by the Scottish scholar and long-serving royal librarian Patrick Young (1584-1652), during the decade or so before his death. The texts he copied here are mainly of canon law. He also added a substitute folio to replace one originally coped by Malaxos, which had been lost. This is one of many Greek manuscripts variously owned, copied, commissioned and annotated by Young. The items copied by him here are mainly canon law texts and lists of ecclesiastical offices from the Byzantine era.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers i-vii in Roman numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right and verso, upper left, then paginated with the numbers 1-13, [13a], 14, [14a], then foliated with the numbers 13-16, 15[a], 16[a], 17-103, 103a, 104-176, 176a, 177-216, [216a], 217 + [a-b], in Arabic numerals, in brown ink recto, upper right.
ff. 47-61 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers [1], 2-15. These numbers have been cancelled.
ff. 67-72 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers 1-6. These numbers have been cancelled.
ff. 75-88 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers 1-6, [7-8], 9-14. These numbers have been cancelled.
ff. 106-113 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers [1], 2-8. These numbers have been cancelled or overwritten.
ff. 114-119 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers [1-2], 3-6. These numbers have been cancelled or overwritten.
ff. 193-199 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in black ink, recto, upper right, with the numbers 1-7.
ff. 211-216 have a previous foliation in Arabic numerals, in black ink and pencil, recto, upper right, with the numbers 1-6.
supportDesc.collation: Part I consists of one quire (Quire 1), Part II of two (Quires 2-3), Part III of one (Quire 4), Part IV of one (Quire 5), Part V of three (Quires 6-8), Part VI of two (Quires 9-10), Part VII of four (Quires 11-14), Part VIII of one (Quire 15), Part IX of six (Quires 16-21), Part X of four (Quires 22-25), Part XI of three (Quires 26-28), Part XII of three (Quires 29-31), Part XIII of six (Quires 32-37), Part XV of three (Quires 38-40), Part XVII of two (Quires 41-42: 17, 2-34, 44, 56+2, 6-84, 94, 108, 11-144, 154, 16-214, 22-254, 26-274, 288, 29-308, 316, 32-368, 378+1, 386, 398, 404, 414+1, 424
supportDesc.condition: Most of f. [216a] has been lost. There are occasional small losses from the edges of other folios. There is slight creasing, and small areas of dirt.

physDesc.additions: There are frequent notes on the texts by Patrick Young, and occasionally by other hands (e.g. ff. i recto and iv recto, pp. 13, and marginal (e.g. pp. 5, 13).

binding.p: 17-century parchment binding over millboards, with plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on patches on the spine.
binding.condition: Some of the parchment covering material has been lost.

history.provenance: Owned by the antiquary Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 , Fellow of Trinity and Dean of York. It appears in the 1697 catalogue of Gale's collection contained in Trinity College MS O.5.38 (pp. 157-158).
history.acquisition: Donated by Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 , in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

msItem.author: Photios I, Patriarch of Constantinople (c. 820-c. 891)
msItem.title: On the mystagogy of the Holy Spirit
msItem.filiation: Copied as excerpted in Euthymios Zigabenos , Panoplia Dogmatica, in Trinity College MS B.8.9
msItem.colophon: f. iv recto Ista descripta sunt ex Euthymii Zigabeni Panoplia, quae servatur manuscripta Graece in Collegio Sancti Trinitatis Cantabrigiae A.D. 1690
msItem.note: ff. ii verso and iv verso are blank

msItem.title: Contents list
msItem.note: f. vii recto-vii verso is blank

support.material:
ff. i-iv Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Coat of arms ( c. 105 63 ) in the gutter.

f. v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Coat of arms ( Unknown Unknown ) in the gutter.
ff. vi-vii Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Letters (EB) ( c. 12 35 ) in the gutter.

list.item: Quire 17 ff. i-vii A disparate quire assembled from folios of various papers.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. i recto-iv recto A single column of 15-20 lines.
172-184 130-140

ff. v recto-vi verso A single column of 27-33 lines.
166-174 125-135

handDesc.handNote: ff. i recto-ii recto, iii recto-iv recto were written by Hand A, in mixed minuscule script of western European type, similar to early printing.
v recto-vi verso were written by Hand B, in Latin script.

history.origin: The Greek text in this part, on ff. i recto-iv recto was copied from a manuscript in Trinity College, Cambridge, in 1690, as indicated by the colophon on f. iv recto. The contents list, on ff. v recto-vi verso, was added at some point after the different parts of the manuscript were bound together, as it includes the full contents.

msItem.title: On bishops
msItem.rubric: p. [13a] Ἐκ τῶν διατάξεων κεφάλαια περὶ ἐπισκόπων
msItem.incipit: p. [13a] Οτι ἔοικεν ἡ ἐκκλησία νηῒ, ὁ μὲν κυβερνήτης ἐστὶν ὁ Χριστὸς

msItem.title: Notes on penances for particular offences
msItem.rubric: p. [14] Περὶ ἐκγληματικῶν κανόνων παρασημείωσις σύντομος, ἐμφαίνουσα τὸ ἁμάρτημα καὶ τοὺς χρόνους τοῦ ἐπιτιμίου
msItem.incipit: p. [14] Ο χειροτονῶν ὑπερόρια, καθαιρείσθω

support.material:
pp. 1-[14a] Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pillar ( c. 65 31 ) in the gutter, comparable to Heawood 3491. This example is dated to 1652.

collation.p: This part consists of two quires, both binia.

layoutDesc.layout: pp. 1-[14a] A single column of 31-37 lines. 165-184 120

handNote.p: pp. 1-[14a], ff. 13r-102v, 106r-119r, 191r-191v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand C) in a western European mixed minuscule script resembling early printing, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.

history.origin: This part was copied by Patrick Young in the mid-17th century, before 1652, as indicated by the watermarks and the date of his death.

msItem.title: Notitia episcopatuum
msItem.filiation: Copied from a manuscript belonging to Thomas Roe, p. 193. The present manuscript is omitted from Darrouzès's list of those containing this text.

support.material:
ff. 91-105 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Pot ( c. 75 28 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to Heawood 3626. This example is dated to 1657.

collation.p: This part consists of four quires, all binia.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 91r-102v A single column of 34-35 lines. 175-180 115
ff. 103r-104r A single column of 35 lines. 165 100-110

handNote.p: pp. 1-[14a], ff. 13r-102v, 106r-119r, 191r-191v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand C) in a western European mixed minuscule script resembling early printing, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
ff. 103r-104r were copied by Hand D in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with moderate variation in letter size.
Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only.
Punctuation used includes the lower and middle points, lower and middle commas and a two-dot colon.

history.origin: Some of this part was copied by Patrick Young in the mid-17th century, before 1652, as indicated by the watermarks and the date of his death.

msItem.author: Symeon, the New Theologian (949-1022)
msItem.note: Traditionally attributed, as here, to John of Damascus (c. 675-c. 749) John, of Damascus, Saint
msItem.title: Epistula de confessione

msItem.author: Peter the Chartophylax
msItem.title: Responsa canonica
msItem.note: Ed. G.A. Rhalles and M. Potles, Σύνταγμα τῶν θείων καὶ ἱερῶν κανόνων..., 6 vols. (Athens 1852-59), vol. 5, pp. 369-373
The order of the questions differs greatly from the edited text

msItem.author: Makarios Chrysokephalos (1300-1382)
msItem.title: Commentary on the Apostolic Canons
msItem.rubric: f. 114r Η παροῦσα ἐξήγησις τῶν ἀποστολικῶν κανόνων ὑπάρχει τοῦ ἀοιδίμου μητροπολίτου Φιλαδελφίας Μακαρίου τοῦ Χρυσοκεφάλου, καὶ χειρὸς ἔργον, καὶ πόνημα φρενός
msItem.incipit: f. 114r Περὶ χειροτονίας τῆς παρὰ ἀρχιερέως τελουμένης ὁ κανὼν διαλέγεται

msItem.title: Hypothesis of the First Council of Nicaea (325)
msItem.rubric: f. 117r Υπόθεσις τῆς ἐν Νικαίᾳ οἰκουμενικῆς πρώτης συνόδου
msItem.incipit: f. 117r Εἶχε μὲν τὰ Ρωμαίων σκῆπτρα Κωνσταντῖνος ὁ Κώνσταντος καὶ Ελένης ὁ μέγας ἐπικληθεὶς

msItem.title: Hypothesis of the First Council of Constantinople (381)
msItem.rubric: f. 119r Υπόθεσις τῆς ἁγίας δευτέρας οἰκουμενικῆς συνόδου
msItem.incipit: f. 119r Η ἁγία οἰκουμενικὴ δευτέρα σύνοδος γέγονεν ἐπὶ βασιλέως Θεοδοσίου τοῦ μεγάλου ἐν Κωνσταντινουπόλει

support.material:
ff. 106-121 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Unidentified motif ( c. 50 56 ) in the gutter.

collation.p: This part consists of three quires, of which two are binia and one is a quaternion.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 106r-119r A single column of 37-44 lines. 186-202 125-135

handNote.p: pp. 1-[14a], ff. 13r-102v, 106r-119r, 191r-191v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand C) in a western European mixed minuscule script resembling early printing, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.

history.origin: This part was copied by Patrick Young, probably in the mid-17th century, before 1652, as indicated by the dates of other parts of the manuscript copied by Young and the date of his death.

msItem.title: Chronicle of the Roman Emperors
msItem.rubric: f. 130r Ἄρξου τοίνυν τοὺς βασιλεῖς Ῥωμαίων
msItem.incipit: f. 130r Ἀκολούθως δὲ, τοὺς Ῥωμαίων βασιλεῖς, καταλέξομεν μικρὸν ἐπαναβάντες τοῖς χρόνοις

msItem.title: Short chronicle
msItem.note: The text here accords with the published text as far as f. 142v, ending with an entry dated 1 October 1520; the remainder of this folio is blank, followed on f. 143r by a single additional entry dated 23 and 26 September 1566, recording the accession of the Ottoman Sultan Selim II

support.material:
ff. 122-138, 143 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Hat ( c. 55 40 ) in the gutter, similar to Piccard online 32090-32091. These examples are dated to 1557-1560.

ff. 139-142 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Anchor ( c. 65 38 ) in the gutter, similar to Piccard online 119129. This example is dated to 1575.

collation.p: This part consists of three quires, of which one is a ternion and the others are quaternia.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 122r-143v A single column of 18-19 lines. 141-147 100

handNote.p: ff. 122r-190v, 193r-207v were copied by Ioannes Malaxos (RGK I 170, II 226, III 282) (Hand E) in mixed minuscule script, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size. There are deletions by expunctuation.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and nomina sacra strokes.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

history.origin: ff. 122r-143v were copied by Ioannes Malaxos (RGK I 170, II 226, III 282) and completed between 1566 and about 1580, as indicated by the watermarks, the scribe's period of activity and the entry for 1566 added to the chronicle on f. 143r.

msItem.title: Description of paintings and funerary monuments in the church of the Pammakaristos
msItem.incipit: f. 145v Εἰς τὸ δεξιὸν μέρος τῆς ἐκκλησίας τοῦ πατριάρχου ὡς σὰν ἐμπένομεν τὴν πόρευαν νὰ ἐλθοῦμαι μέσα εἰς τὴν ἐκκλησίαν

msItem.title: Notes on the church of the Pammakaristos
msItem.incipit: f. 160v Τῆς δεξιᾶς μερέας· ἡλιακὸν δίσκον σε παρθένε βλέπων

msItem.author: Ioannes Malaxos
msItem.title: Description of the gates of Constantinople
msItem.rubric: f. 162r Αἱ Θύραι τῆς Κωνσταντινουπόλεως
msItem.incipit: f. 162r Πρώτη πόρτα τοῦ σαραγίου ἡ αὐθεντικὴ

msItem.title: Poem on the conspiracy of Prokopios against Valens, from an inscription from the walls of Chalcedon
msItem.rubric: f. 165r Ὁ βασιλεὺς Οὐαλεντινιανὸς ὁ μέγας, συγκοινωνὸν ἐποίησε τῆς βασιλείας αὐτοῦ, Οὐαλέντα τὸν ἀδελφὸν αὐτοῦ...
msItem.incipit: f. 165r Αλλ'ὅτε δὴ νύμφαι ἱερὸν κατὰ ἄστυ χορείην

msItem.title: Recipe for ink
msItem.rubric: f. 165v Σκευασία τοῦ μέλανος
msItem.incipit: f. 165v Ζἀκκος δράμια

msItem.title: Acrostic poem
msItem.rubric: f. 166r Τῶν ὧδε θυρῶν Χριστὸς πάρἐστι φύλαξ
msItem.incipit: f. 166r Αἴγλης παμφαοῦς Θῶκος τῆς γε ἐν Θέου
msItem.note: The lines are divided into two, the acrostic phrase being formed by the initial letters of the first part of each line, followed by those of the second part of each line, then the final letters of each line: Ἀνδρέας Θεότοκε ὑμνεῖ σε

msItem.title: List of members of the family of the Emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus (905-959)
msItem.incipit: f. 166r Κωνσταντῖνος ὁ πορφυρογέννητος, υἱὸς Λέοντος τοῦ σοφοῦ

msItem.filiation: This manuscript is omitted from Darrouzès's list of those containing this text.

msItem.title: List of the kings of Israel and Judah, kings of Assyria, Ptolemaic kings and Roman emperors to John VIII Palaiologos (1392-1448)
msItem.rubric: f. 169v Περὶ βασιλέων τῶν Ἰουδαίων
msItem.incipit: f. 169v αʹ Σαοὺλ φυλῆς Βενιαμὶν, ἔτη, μʹ

msItem.title: Chronology from Adam to the Emperor Constantine I (d. 337)
msItem.incipit: Ἀπὸ Ἀδὰμ, ἕως τῆς τελευτῆς Ἀλεξάνδρου· ἔτη, ͵ερξζʹ

msItem.title: List of ecclesiastical provinces transferred from Rome to Constantinople

msItem.title: List of Popes (to Honorius I (d. 638)), Patriarchs of Jerusalem (to Modestos (d. 634)), Alexandria (to Peter IV (d. 651)), Antioch (to Anastasios I (d. 598)) and Constantinople (to Isaias (d. 1332))

msItem.title: Notes on the names of plants

msItem.title: Notes on measures

msItem.incipit: f. 180r Ἴστεον ὅτι τὸ κεράτιον, τὸ ἰδιωτικῶς λεγόμενον κοκκίον

msItem.title: Recipes for medicines, inks, soaps etc
msItem.incipit: Περὶ συλλήψεως γυναικός: Περὶ γυναικὸς ἵνα ἔγγυος γένηται

msItem.title: Note recording the deposition of Patriarch Ioasaph II (8 January 1565)
msItem.incipit: f. 185v Μηνὶ Ἰαννουαρίῳ, ηʹ· ἐκάθηραν τὸν πατράρχον τὸν Ἰωάσαφ· καὶ ἡμερὰ βʹ εἰς τὰς ιʹ τοῦ αὐτοῦ μηνὸς ἐποίησαν τὸν Μητροφάνην πατριάρχην· καὶ ἦσαν ἀρχιερεῖς ξʹ τὸν ἀριθμὸν· καὶ καὶ ἐκάθησεν εἰς τὸν ὑψηλότατον θρόνον ἡμέρα, δʹ
msItem.note: This is the full text of this item

msItem.title: Note on the Xerolophos column
msItem.rubric: f. 185v Περὶ τοῦ Ξηρολόφου
msItem.incipit: f. 185v Ξηρολόφος· ὅτι τὸν ξηρολόφον, πρώην μὲν θέμα τινὲς ἐκάλουν

support.material:
ff. 144-190 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Bull's head ( c. 75 36 ) in the gutter, similar to Piccard online 67981-67983. These examples are dated to 1565-1568.

collation.p: This part consists of six quires, all quaternia.

list.item: Quire 378+ ff. 183-191 A single later folio (f. 191, described as Part XIV) has been adhered to the end of this quire.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire of this part, recto, lower centre, beginning from the number 2. They survive on all quires (βʹ-ζʹ).

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 144r-190v A single column of 13-23 lines. 147-160 95-120

handNote.p: ff. 122r-190v, 193r-207v were copied by Ioannes Malaxos (RGK I 170, II 226, III 282) (Hand E) in mixed minuscule script, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size. There are deletions by expunctuation.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and nomina sacra strokes.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

history.origin: ff. 144r-190v were copied by Ioannes Malaxos (RGK I 170, II 226, III 282) and completed between 1572 and 1587, as indicated by the watermarks, the scribe's period of activity and the content relating to the church of the Pammakaristos . This content, believed to be original, must date from later than 1572, when the son of the voivod Alexander of Moldavia, whose tomb is mentioned here, is last recorded as having been alive, and before the church's seizure by the Ottoman government in 1587.

support.material:
f. 191 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Anchor ( Unknown 40 )

supportDesc.collation: This part consists of a single folio adhered to Quire 37.

layoutDesc.layout: f. 191r-191v A single column of 30 lines. 161 120

handNote.p: pp. 1-[14a], ff. 13r-102v, 106r-119r, 191r-191v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand C) in a western European mixed minuscule script resembling early printing, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.

history.origin: f. 191r-191v was copied and inserted to replace a lost original folio by Patrick Young, probably in the mid-17th century, before 1652, as indicated by the dates of other parts of the manuscript copied by Young and the date of his death..

support.material:
ff. 192r-209v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Anchor ( c. 65 38 ) in the gutter, similar to Mošin 1381. This example is dated to 1565-1575.

collation.p: This part consists of three quires, of which one is a binion, one a ternion and one a quaternion.
collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire of this part, recto, lower centre, beginning from the number 2. They survive on all quires (βʹ-ζʹ).

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 193r-207v A single column of 17-18 lines. 146 110

handNote.p: ff. 122r-190v, 193r-207v were copied by Ioannes Malaxos (RGK I 170, II 226, III 282) (Hand E) in mixed minuscule script, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size. There are deletions by expunctuation.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and nomina sacra strokes.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

history.origin: This part was copied by Patrick Young in the mid-17th century, before 1652, as indicated by the watermarks and the date of his death.

support.material: f. 210 Western paper, folded in quarto.

supportDesc.collation: This is a single folio adhered to Quire 41.

msItem.note: This text is written on recto folios only, the versos being left blank

msItem.title: Letter from Andronikos to Demetrios
msItem.incipit: f. 215v Ἀνδρόνικος Δημητρίω, εὖ πράττειν: οὔτε πρότερον διὰ χρόνου σε ἐπιστείχαντα ᾐτιασάμην αὐτός

support.material:
ff. 211-217 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark:
Hat ( c. 70 46 ) in the gutter, similar to Briquet 3409. This example is dated to 1519-1527.

collation.p: This part consists of two quires, both binia.

list.item: Quire 414+1 ff. 210-214 A single later folio (f. 210, described as Part XVI) has been adhered to the beginning of this quire.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 211r-216v A single column of 25-27 lines. 183-196 140-150

handNote.p: f. 211r, lines 1-19 was copied by Hand F in mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, with significant variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and breathings.
Punctuation used includes the lower and middle points, lower and middle commas and a two-dot colon.
f. 211r, line 19-f. 216v were copied by Hand G in mixed minuscule script, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and breathings.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower commas, a two-dot colon and the full stop.

history.origin: This part was copied in the first half of the 16th century, as suggested by the watermarks. This is consistent with the style of script.
